title: Will there be 12 or more Chapter 9 municipal bankruptcy filings in 2020?
preds: Can't see any news in the comments of a surge of Chapter 9's. As the number of chapter 9s which would have to take place in the last quarter for this to come true would be, or close to, unprecedented I think it would have been covered in the news. So going down to zero chance for the last days of the year. Yes: -4
There could be a bankruptcy surge in 2021.

Going down a bit more. Should have been some news (in general and here) if there was several chapter 9s being filed. As previously noted the number of chapter 9s for the period Oct 2019-Sep 2020 was 4 which means there has to be a at least 8 (probably more) chapter 9s in the last quarter for this to come true. Yes: -5
mark to market, 4 YTD, before year-end w/ holidays seems unlikely
Biden admin will want to support - Can't file for Ch9 if you have not exhausted all options
Rolling 12 month on sept report has 4 filings, so feels very unlikely now.
updating for passage of time, 6 weeks left

/No stimulus/federal aid before election
/Transition is slow
/Transition is uncertain, as the election will remain under scrutiny for a while (recounts, law suits) and the target for attempted delegitimization, thus federal aid likely not before February 2021
/Balance of Power (House vs Senate) uncertain: Senate Republicans could continue to block important federal legislation in order to sabotage the incoming government of 46 POTUS and make it appear failing
/Spending remains elevated
/risk of "accidental default" for technical reasons (deadline, administrative failure,...) higher than on average due to political turmoil and elevated workload within municipalities (election year, health crisis, economic crisis, education crisis, risk of key faculty on sick leave at crucial times due to virus exposure,...)
Given last year was a relatively good financial year, it'd seem a doubling in Chapter 12 filing seems double the likelihood versus not

I am lowering my prediction after seeing the quarter ending Sept. 30 showing a total of 4 Chp. 9 filings thus far this calendar year. There will likely still be fallout as a result of the pandemic but will probably not be fully seen until 2021.

If I read the numbers correctly there has been 4 Chapter 9 filings in the period Oct 2019-Sep 2020.[1] If I'm reading the data correctly it means there will have to be at least 8 chapter 9 filings in the last quarter of this year. There is a high probability I'm misunderstanding the data, but as that is what I have to go on I'm lowering my prediction of this happening. If someone can correct my reading or reaffirm it I would be grateful. Yes: -9 1. https://www.uscourts.gov/statistics-reports/caseload-statistics-data-tables?tn=F-5A&pn=32&t=534&m%5Bvalue%5D%5Bmonth%5D=&y%5Bvalue%5D%5Byear%5D=2020 See September 30 2020 report, page 132

The Fed access lending is helping to keep many on the edge of bankruptcy but not filling. Strategically, a municipality that does not borrow the max possible from the Fed lending facility and then does not files for bankruptcy is not acting on the best interest of its citizens given the present situation. No more or less what corporations are doing now.

There have been 2 Chapter 9 filings since April 2020, as per Courts stats, (to be used to determine outcome, as per Q above).
All else appears to be speculative nonsense.
 https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f2.1_0630.2020.pdf Year on year totals: https://abi-org.s3.amazonaws.com/Newsroom/Bankruptcy_Statistics/Chapter9Filings1980-Current.pdf

Many (maybe most; it's been a long time since I needed to know this) US municipalities use the calendar year as their fiscal year, so their budgets must be in place by 31 December.  That means they will confront the reality of their '21 budgets starting in the next few weeks, although many will put off the final stage (panicky negotiations and wholesale fudging) until early November.   Staying slightly higher than consensus in case when they get to that stage, at least a dozen will figure out that Chapter 9 is what they have instead of hope.

Going down slightly since the number of bankruptcies seem pretty stable. For the year 30 June 2019- 30 June 2020 the number of chapter 9 was six.[1] Nothing out of the ordinary seem to be happening at the moment. Will watch out for the numbers that will be released for the period 30 Sept 2019-30 Sept 2020.[2] Yes: -2 1. https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f5a_0630.2020.pdf page 133
2. https://www.uscourts.gov/statistics-reports/caseload-statistics-data-tables?tn=F-5A&pn=32&t=534&m%5Bvalue%5D%5Bmonth%5D=&y%5Bvalue%5D%5Byear%5D=2019
Federal Reserve via the Main Street Lending program will prevent bankruptcy filings above 12

Also however, Republican voter base mainly recruits from white rural non-college educated voters, so the strategy may just work as planned and send a few but significant municipalities over the brink to "see what happens", before finally any money will be released.

Ticking up slightly higher - had been surprised a deal in congress hadn't been concluded Who knew a populist president with weak ratings, (but dominating the majority party in the Senate) wouldn't dole out cash on the electorate right before the election...
Any further delay in federal fiscal stimulus and municipal finance assistance could rush at least a few very weak, mostly smaller and/or rural municipalities into Chapter 9 bankruptcy filing.
I lack conviction. Following the crowd.

Revised forecast, taking into consideration evidence provided by crowd.  *For myself, the specificity of the Chapter, (the requisite conditions for filing and the fact we are now in August,) suggest to me a lower likelihood. Furthermore, I can find no evidence of further/recent chapter 12 filings?
Average over the past decade is 6 per year, therefore there is a likelihood that this year will see a larger than average number of Chapter 9 filings.
6 filings on June report, assuming I’m looking at the right data.
Fed's Municipal Liquidity Facility should provide some cushion.
Currently at 3 chapter 9 filings for 2020. Seems unlikely to reach 12, but you know, 2020 is a crazy year, so anything could happen.

Having thoroughly read the actions and definitions [1], that both necessitate and grant Chapter 9 proceedings, it appears an unlikely event that 12 such instances should occur in this timeframe (or, rather, 6 more); esp. given historical data and requisite contexts...  [1] https://www.uscourts.gov/services-forms/bankruptcy/bankruptcy-basics/chapter-9-bankruptcy-basics

Q2 F-5A was posted to uscourts.gov today. The news is mostly expected, there have been 4 Chapter 9 bankruptcies so far in 2020. In addition to the previous 3 identified (Jack County, TX, Douglas County, NE and Jefferson County, AL) there was a second bankruptcy in Jack County, TX. In line with previous analysis, in order to reach 12 municipal bankruptcies, there will need to be 8 more this year. 8 bankruptcies in 6 months would be an extremely high rate. Since my last forecast, we also have a lot more certainty in our data, as we have the official totals through July 1. Using historic data, we can adjust our estimates down and be more confident in our prediction.

Latest filings show no new Chapter 9 bankruptcies in Q2. [1] Consquently cutting forecast by 5 percent. [1] https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f5a_0630.2020.pdf (See Page 133)

Base rate: 8.3 bankruptcies on average over last 20 years Reasons for up: 
- COVID has greatly impacted cities and municipalities, especially hospitals and healthcare centers. 
- US in recession Reasons for down:
- $2 Trillion stimulus package included $150 billion for state, county, and municipal governments, as well as $100 billion for local hospitals and allows U.S. Treasury to authorize $500 billion in loans and municipal bond purchases. With a second stimulus package being worked on in the government, there is good hope that this will shelter the burden felt by cities and healthcare centers
- Each of the four highest occurrences of bankruptcies was a year following a recession, suggesting some historical lagging effect. 
- As of July 28, there have only been two reported municipality bankruptcies: Fairfield, Alabama and Jack County Texas. Thus, we would have to have 10 more bankruptcies in five months in order to reach the condition.
As a result, I am bullish on there being 12 or more, but will do more research and speak with my team members to get their opinion. Sources:
https://www.nj.com/coronavirus/2020/07/senate-republicans-unveil-1t-plan-that-includes-2nd-stimulus-check-lower-unemployment-benefits-what-happens-next.html
https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/04/coronavirus-cities-bankruptcy/609169/
updating to reflect likely lag of impact from recession to municpal filings, as well as potential for federal funds to backstop state/local governments

Staying the course but feel strenghtened in this:
"Fox News is told Republicans are looking at $100 billion of the $1 trillion to go to state and local governments" - a sign that there are still carrots being dangled in front of lower governments - muddying the water whether it's 100% necessary to go through CH9 pains https://www.foxnews.com/politics/mcconnell-says-economy-needs-another-shot-of-adrenaline-says-he-supports-another-round-of-coronavirus-stimulus-checks
As economies improve and additional stimulus is available the likelihood is decreasing

Since 1980 there has been an average of 8.2 municipal bankruptcies per year. Obviously, 2020 is anything but a typical year. Although it is not official yet, we are likely in a recession in the United States (we will not know for certain until GDP estimates of the past 6 months are finalized). 2020 is also an election year, which likely has a small impact on the number of municipal bankruptcies, as local election calendars are not overly correlated with the timing of national elections. In years of recession, however, there have an average number of municipal bankruptcies. In 1981 and 1982 three were 2 and 3 bankruptcies respectively. 1990 and 1991 experienced 19 and 13. 2001 brought 8 bankruptcies. In 2008 there were only 4 bankruptcies. There seems to be a lagging trend in the data, that bankruptcies increase in the years following a recession. The most recent year we had 12 or more bankruptcies was 2012. I used the 2020 Q1 F-5A LTM report and compared it to the 2019 Year End report to calculate the number of chapter 9 bankruptcies in the US so far. As of 3/31, there had been 2 Chapter 9 bankruptcies: one in Jack County, Texas and one in Douglas County, Nebraska. Since the end of March, there has been one notable chapter 9 bankruptcy so far in Fairfield, Alabama. This brings us to an estimated total of 3 this year. I will update this as Q2 filings become available. I compared commercial bankruptcy data to municipal bankrupt data, through the two metrics are not entirely correlated with one another. Municipalities will be hit with lower tax revenues this year, but not as badly as state and federal governments. Sales tax makes up only 7% of municipal revenue on average, with intergovernmental transfers and property taxes accounting for over 65% of revenues. Because the coronavirus pandemic strongly depressed retail spending, but has had less of an impact on real estate, I do not expect that the coronavirus will be as big a catalyst for municipal bankruptcies as it may seem, though intergovernmental transfers will be affected. Costs will be exceptionally high this year. Hospitals and healthcare centers will continue to shoulder the financial burden of the pandemic. I think the majority of municipal governments have benefitted from the longest economic expansion in US history, which ended earlier this year. Because the coronavirus pandemic’s resulting recession is unique from other financial crisis we’ve experience in the past forty years, I think it will have less of an impact on municipal bankruptcies. My prediction, and hope, is that municipalities are not as cash strapped given the recent economic expansion. I do not think local governments will be as hard hit as state and the federal government. In the past 38 years, there have only been 5 years which had over 12 municipal bankruptcies. 1 of these 5 years occurred in the first year of a recession. I think we are still at greater risk this year that this base rate. My estimate is that there is a 30% chance of having 12 or more municipal bankruptcies this year. This would imply 9 in the next 6 months. https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/briefing-book/what-are-sources-revenue-local-governments
https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2020/04/coronavirus-cities-bankruptcy/609169/

Let’s reread the question!  There were 6 filings in the 12 months to March 2020.  Compared to December when there were also 6 in the last 12 months this suggested there have already been 3 filings during 2020. Higher probability of getting to 12.
Bankruptcies have a lag time on them and coivd19 kicked off in March 2020.  Lower probability of getting to 12.
12 in 2020 is double the current rolling 12 month number.  Lower probability of getting 12.
Bankruptcies might be seen as an easier way out of a tough spot with covid19.  Higher probability of getting to 12.
Keeping forecast high, but lower than my previous forecast.  
Need to see the June returns, which should be published soon.
Dialing down yet again... then holding steady til late fall unless the news changes

Prior: there have been 167 bankruptcies 2000-2019, averaging 8.35 per year, and with 4 years surpassing 12, so my prior will be 20%. 
https://www.statista.com/statistics/1118479/bankruptcy-filings-us-chapter-9-municipality/ Reasons for higher:
1. I paired all the years' data with GDP growth rate and tried to run a simple regression (it was statistically insignificant, so I decided to not use it). However, just by looking at the numbers, the highest years are 2019, 2011, 2012, and 2014, the years following the great recession. Also, 11 were declared in 2000, the end of the dot com bubble burst. Given the huge impact of COVID on GDP growth, I would revise up my estimate by 15%.
2. Looking at historical data, about 1/3 of the bankruptcies were declared by hospitals and healthcare munis. This is extremely concerning, given COVID effectively ended elective procedures around the country, which usually count about 30% of impatient revenue. Again, I revise up by 25% because of this, though it's hard to give a quantitative estimate of the financial impact on hospitals for now.
3. Mitch McConnell opened supported the route of having munis declare Chapter 9 instead of giving them bailouts. Up 5%. Reasons for lower:
1. When pairing Chapter 9 number and GDP, there seems to have a lagging effect. In other words, usually it's the years that follow financial distress that witness more bankruptcies, so I will revise down 5%.
2. Many munis were in great financial health coming into this year, but again, these munis are the strongest in financial health and are least likely to declare bankruptcies. So I will revise down another 5% 20+15+25+5-5-5 = 55%

12 happened in 2009, 3 has happened so far, expect more financial pressure with second COVID resurgence but still think it is rather unlikely that 12 will be surpassed especially with strong fiscal and monetary policy.

https://www.usmayors.org/issues/covid-19/fiscal-pain-tracker/

Lowering two points simply due to passage of time. Obviously all eyes on 6/30/20 F5-A, which should be coming soon? (Can't find release schedule.  Anyone have details?) If that shows three or fewer filings, I'll probably cut in half. Four or five, I probably sit tight at current forecast. Six or more, will start to increase meaningfully. " while bankruptcy protection may be necessary to buy time to consummate such a financing and delay disruptive collections efforts or the forced liquidation of collateral, all efforts should be made to convince creditors to be patient and not to cause the municipality to incur the significant costs associated with a bankruptcy filing" https://s3.amazonaws.com/cdn.orrick.com/files/Chapter9vChapter11ComparisonChartLevinsonPLB.pdf
Municipalities cannot be put into Chapter 9 involuntarily. Section 303 of the Bankruptcy Code, which provides for the commencement of involuntary cases, is not applicable in Chapter 9 It must also show "It has negotiated in good faith with creditors but failed to reach an agreement"

Dialing down a touch with further passage of time.  Original logic below... ---- Longterm base rate quite low...didn’t count, but graph looks like around 10%. Reinforcing a number in that range are the numbers from the most recent recession: first spike trailed by two years, with peak four years following beginning of recession. This seems like a strong signal that a spike of magnitude in question is very unlikely this year. Another simple factor reinforcing my 10%-ish instinct: it appears that there have only been two Chapter 9s filed so far in 2020––one in the most recent F-5A report [2], and one reported in the news this week [3]. With approximately 40% of the year gone, that leaves a very steep climb to get to 12 over seven months. However, one issue not discussed in any comments so far is that public hospitals are one of the types of municipalities that can file under Chapter 9. COVID is placing immense fiscal strain on hospitals generally [4]. I couldn’t find articles specific to challenges faced by public hospitals, but I assume that it would be similar or worse, with respect to private hospitals. There were only 61 public hospital BKs under Chapter 9 between 1980 and 2018 (1.6 per year), but if we were to see several times that base rate this year (which seems plausible given the nature of the crisis)––perhaps six hospitals––and then add that to the longterm average of non-hospital Chapter 9s (6.5 per year), then your’e right above the threshold. I would be in the 10-15% range if not for this hospital bit, for which I increase to 22%. If we don’t see a surge of Chapter 9s in the next couple of months, I’ll be dialing this down quickly. All figures above are from [1] unless noted otherwise. [1] https://muninetguide.com/municipal-bankruptcy-statistics/
[2] https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f2.3_0331.2020.pdf
[3] https://www.al.com/news/2020/05/city-of-fairfield-files-for-bankruptcy.html
[4] https://www.wsj.com/articles/sending-hospitals-into-bankruptcy-11587326607

I like to point to the 580K job lost in the May job report. That's an indicator of a tight budgetary prospect for governments. Loss of revenue because of COVID-19 can not be recovered in any form other than direct money in the form of Federal Fiscal policy. It is very likely that compared to 2019 (six) we would reach twice that (12) bankruptcies year. The only thing that can change this is political will that is very unlikely to come to fruition this year and without a slew of bankruptcies as evidence of the worsening problem. With no grime outlook, there won't be any political attention to this problem.

I don't believe there is much of an incentive in an election year to let a large number of local governments fail. Still, a small number of badly administered local government might well fail, and, depending on the course of the pandemic over the next several months, others might follow in 2021.

6 municipalities declared bankruptcy last year, when the economy was still in good standing. This year, with a pandemic-induced recession, any municipality that was on the brink of financial issues will suffer from diminished incomes. It seems highly likely therefore that we should see at least double the number of last year's bankruptcy filings.

I agree with Leonardthethird's analysis offered below and having included some of my own thoughts afterwards. Leonard's take:  Original logic below. Adjusting downward simply due to elapsed time without any signal suggesting that probability of "Yes" is increasing. Still appear to have been only 2 Chapter 9s so far in 2020. No news reports suggesting any others are imminent at this time. ---- Longterm base rate quite low...didn’t count, but graph looks like around 10%. Reinforcing a number in that range are the numbers from the most recent recession: first spike trailed by two years, with peak four years following beginning of recession. This seems like a strong signal that a spike of magnitude in question is very unlikely this year. Another simple factor reinforcing my 10%-ish instinct: it appears that there have only been two Chapter 9s filed so far in 2020––one in the most recent F-5A report [2], and one reported in the news this week [3]. With approximately 40% of the year gone, that leaves a very steep climb to get to 12 over seven months. However, one issue not discussed in any comments so far is that public hospitals are one of the types of municipalities that can file under Chapter 9. COVID is placing immense fiscal strain on hospitals generally [4]. I couldn’t find articles specific to challenges faced by public hospitals, but I assume that it would be similar or worse, with respect to private hospitals. There were only 61 public hospital BKs under Chapter 9 between 1980 and 2018 (1.6 per year), but if we were to see several times that base rate this year (which seems plausible given the nature of the crisis)––perhaps six hospitals––and then add that to the longterm average of non-hospital Chapter 9s (6.5 per year), then your’e right above the threshold. I would be in the 10-15% range if not for this hospital bit, for which I increase to 22%. If we don’t see a surge of Chapter 9s in the next couple of months, I’ll be dialing this down quickly. All figures above are from [1] unless noted otherwise. [1] https://muninetguide.com/municipal-bankruptcy-statistics/
[2] https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f2.3_0331.2020.pdf
[3] https://www.al.com/news/2020/05/city-of-fairfield-files-for-bankruptcy.html
[4] https://www.wsj.com/articles/sending-hospitals-into-bankruptcy-11587326607 My support: I like your thinking here. Started out on the more positve side but as it turns out my gut couldn't be trusted. After reading your analysis, I dug into some other statistics. I thought that with unemployment rising as a result of COVID-19, foreclosures might rise which would cascade into property taxes - the main source of local i.e. municipal income, putting many places under pressure. According to the latest statstics, 72 percent of local and state revenue comes from property taxes. This is down from 80 percent in 1977. [1] So states have succeeded in diversifying somewhat but are still very dependent on this one revenue stream. Where my argument breaks down is that foreclosures are actually back to Q1 2005 lows before the housing crisis ramped up. In fact, foreclosure rates are back to pre-recession levels in 61 percent of the US. [2] While some may read this as the calm before the storm, and with good reason perhaps, it does mean that localities have breathing room before things get really dire. This is crucial to the timing element of the question, of course. Most states are actually in relatively healthy financial positions based on the most current information I could find with a brief search.[3] All this combined with your analysis leads me to think that most places will be able to weather the storm this year and while things might get difficult it won't push bankrupcies into uncharted territory as you mentioned. Hope this information might be encouraging and helpful. [1] https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/statistics/local-property-taxes-percentage-local-tax-revenue
[2] https://www.attomdata.com/news/market-trends/foreclosures/attom-data-solutions-q1-2020-u-s-foreclosure-market-report/
[3] https://www.mercatus.org/publications/urban-economics/state-fiscal-rankings

According to comments there have been two this far this year which I adjust to.  When you look at the financial crisis of 2008-2009 there are 10 chapter 9 bankruptcies 2009, but 13 and 12 2011 and 2012. While the pandemic crisis certainly will have far reaching economic consequences for municipalities I believe most of them are 1-3 years ahead. Right now economic considerations is in a state of exception and put on hold until further notice. When normalcy is returned I believe municipalities will try to find other ways to solve their economic problems before going to chapter 9.
If the question had been if there will be 12 or more Chapter 9 municipal bankruptcy filings in 2020, 2021 or 2022 I would put the probability well above 50%.

Original logic below. Adjusting downward simply due to elapsed time without any signal suggesting that probability of "Yes" is increasing.  Still appear to have been only 2 Chapter 9s so far in 2020.  No news reports suggesting any others are imminent at this time. ---- Longterm base rate quite low...didn’t count, but graph looks like around 10%. Reinforcing a number in that range are the numbers from the most recent recession: first spike trailed by two years, with peak four years following beginning of recession. This seems like a strong signal that a spike of magnitude in question is very unlikely this year. Another simple factor reinforcing my 10%-ish instinct: it appears that there have only been two Chapter 9s filed so far in 2020––one in the most recent F-5A report [2], and one reported in the news this week [3]. With approximately 40% of the year gone, that leaves a very steep climb to get to 12 over seven months. However, one issue not discussed in any comments so far is that public hospitals are one of the types of municipalities that can file under Chapter 9. COVID is placing immense fiscal strain on hospitals generally [4]. I couldn’t find articles specific to challenges faced by public hospitals, but I assume that it would be similar or worse, with respect to private hospitals. There were only 61 public hospital BKs under Chapter 9 between 1980 and 2018 (1.6 per year), but if we were to see several times that base rate this year (which seems plausible given the nature of the crisis)––perhaps six hospitals––and then add that to the longterm average of non-hospital Chapter 9s (6.5 per year), then your’e right above the threshold. I would be in the 10-15% range if not for this hospital bit, for which I increase to 22%. If we don’t see a surge of Chapter 9s in the next couple of months, I’ll be dialing this down quickly. All figures above are from [1] unless noted otherwise. [1] https://muninetguide.com/municipal-bankruptcy-statistics/
[2] https://www.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/data_tables/bf_f2.3_0331.2020.pdf
[3] https://www.al.com/news/2020/05/city-of-fairfield-files-for-bankruptcy.html
[4] https://www.wsj.com/articles/sending-hospitals-into-bankruptcy-11587326607

The downturn in the economy 2008-2011 is comparable to now. Many small towns don’t have the budgets to cover emergency needs. In my rather prosperous town they are going to have layoffs and pay roll backs for government workers. Without Federal Aid to States that they can pass to cities there is no way they are going all make it. Maybe because of 2008 cities are better prepared but the cost here in terms of no taxes is unprecedented. I am raising this slightly a little above 50%.

I'm just getting into my first forecasts on the GJ site, and I really appreciate all the links and comments provided by others.  They give me a good place to start.  After digesting it to the extent that I'm able to right now, I'm starting at the low end.  I think the federal govt may see it in its best interest to prevent bankruptcies to the greatest extent possible in order to avoid negative economic news as we head towards the 2020 elections.
Adjusting to the crowd and per research below.

Over the last 20 years, the base rate for this (>12 municipal bankruptcy filings) has been 10%. Around the 2007/2008 recession, the highest point was 10 bankruptcies in 2009, indicating a lag. So a priori, despite the bad situation, we wouldn't expect bankruptcies to turn up this year. But maybe the loss in revenue is so great that they'll be forced to act sooner. In 2009, this sheet (https://www2.census.gov/govs/pubs/state_loc_gov/state_loc_gov_2009.pdf) indicates that local government revenues minus expenditures summed for a shortfall of $200 billion. Assuming the current shortfall will be broadly similar, then 3/4 of the shortfall will be mitigated by the government's stimulus. In addition, it's not clear that property values will fall as they did during the 08 recession, and property taxes make up a significant portion of municipal revenue: in 2009 they constituted 3/4 of all municipal tax revenue. Still, the situation is unusual, so I inflate my estimate form 10% to 25%.

- Last peak in bankruptcies was 2009 - 2014, predominantly by special purpose districts (healthcare a major one).  Right after 2008 housing crash.
- There tends to be a lag in bankruptcy filings (1 - 2 years after an event.)  Took about 9 months after 2008 market crash for filings to begin.  I would suspect more in 2021/2022 than 2020
- Some states require their authorization for a bankruptcy filing - The states that allow municipal bankruptcy without state approval are the larger populated states.  Perhaps this increases likelihood of more filings this year
- These bankruptcy filings were predominantly in states where municipalities do not need state authorization
- One so far this year - Fairfield in AL.  Will others be influences to follow suit or will local governments hate the thought?  Election year....
- Only 7 months left in 2020, so tempering likelihood of reaching 12 bankruptcies but wary that healthcare special districts tends to be the most impacted
- I believe Feds will attempt to support favored cities from bankruptcy - a total mix of red state/blue state in the 2010 - 2014 bankruptcies - I think it will be hard to reach 12 this year so I give it a base of 15%
- Heavily populated cities are already struggling financially so 5% more
- The recent Fed $1.8B influx into muni bonds is a leading indicator of bankruptcies so 5% more https://www.pewtrusts.org/en/research-and-analysis/fact-sheets/2018/02/local-governments-rarely-file-for-bankruptcy
https://www.governing.com/gov-data/municipal-cities-counties-bankruptcies-and-defaults.html
https://catalyst.independent.org/2019/07/09/are-u-s-cities-fiscally-insolvent/
http://www.munibondadvisor.com/market.htm

The worst year for Chapter 9 filings were 2011 and 2009 (with 13 and 12 filings respectively). Local governments will be be hit by a double whammy due to the Covid19 pandemic. They will have increasing costs due to healthcare and citizen services related heads, while having to deal with a 80% to 90% fall in revenue from sources like sales tax and property tax. This will be a pretty unique situation, one which has not been seen even during the times of the GFC. There could be a lag effect which could push actual filings to CY 2021 (but the pandemic might accelerate things, unlike a steady downturn which could take years to play out). Chapter 9 could be expanded to include States also - but we could ignore the impact of this (50 states vs 1000s of other local government bodies).  The city of Fairfield, Alabama has just filed for Chapter 9. Though they have been in financial trouble for long, the pandemic pushed them over. Hence going with an initial estimate of 40%. - https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/briefing-book/what-are-sources-revenue-local-governments
- https://www.pressconnects.com/story/news/local/2020/03/20/municipalities-brace-revenue-plummet-how-hurt-taxpayers/2869004001/
- https://www.bondbuyer.com/news/fairfield-alabama-files-for-chapter-9-bankruptcy

Base rate appears to be ~20% according to the table in the MuniNet source. However, I'm not sure how much the base rate tells us since the economic downturn that's gonna happen this year hasn't happened in the past century. I think the 1990-1991 recession is among the best indicators for what could happen this time (since that also started early in the year), which implies that the probability is a lot higher than 20%. Another issue is that there is a bit of a lag in the data; since the pandemic started so early in the year, though, I think many of the bankruptcies will happen in late 2020 as opposed to 2021. Will need to come back to this question often at the end of the year.

Only happened 4 times in last 10 years (Statista) - but reducing base rate because
- seems to be a lag (2009 had 12 filings, '08 only 4)
- bankrupting municipalities in election year is bad press
- CoV 19 is externality
therefore expecting a lot more federal & state relief / negotiation to take place before biting the bullet
Kneejerk baseline... will reevaluate and reconsider with more research.
